docs.lead_paragraph: As the last day of the regular legislative session wore on this morning, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders had not yet reached agreements on a host of major bills, among them one to extend rent regulations. It appeared that the 2003 session was in danger of being notable as much for what had not been done as for what had been done. The long night of strained and often fruitless negotiations capped a contentious six months in which the Legislature passed a budget over the governor's vetoes. Many legislators said the wounds from that conflict had yet to heal and ill feelings hindered compromise.

headline.main: Time Running Out, Albany Is Stymied On Major Measures

docs.abstract: New York Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders, facing final day of regular legislative session, fail to reach agreement on host of mjaor bills, among them one to extend rent regulations; Pataki and colleagues in Senate majority throw all-night negotiations into turmoil by passing surprise bill that would extend rent regulations for eight years; meanwhile, Assembly Democrats pass two versions of their own bill, one a four-year extension and other a one-year extension; it remains unclear how impasse will be resolved as current regulations expire; so many issues remain open that Assembly leaders say they plan to return later in morning, but Senate says it will finish its business before daybreak and adjourn for summer, leaving open possibility that Legislature will have unfinished business to resolve in fall; array of pending bills discussed; photos (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday that city schools had undercounted the number of teenage mothers by many thousands. The comptroller's report said that at least 8,368 teenage mothers were recorded by the Department of Health between the 1997 and 2000 school years, yet city schools reported an annual average of only 150 pregnant students for those years. In a statement, the Board of Education said it shared the comptroller's concerns and would continue working with him on meeting these students' needs. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Challenge On Teen Mothers

docs.abstract: New York City Comptroller William C Thompson Jr reports that 8,386 teenage mothers were recorded by Dept of Health between 1997 and 2000 school years, but that schools reported only 150 pregnant students each year; Board of Education says it will work with Thompson on meeting these students' needs; photo (S)

byline.original: By Stacy Albin (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: The state House has approved a bill intended to offset the costs of malpractice insurance for rural doctors. The measure would set up a $10 million fund to subsidize insurance premiums for doctors, particularly those offering obstetrics. The bill's sponsors contend that large payouts in medical malpractice suits are causing doctors' insurance rates to rise, making it difficult for small rural practices to survive. The bill now goes to the Senate. Dave Miller, a spokesman for Senate Democrats, said it had a good chance of passing. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Insurance Aid For Rural Doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Daughter-in-Law,'' a play by D. H. Lawrence, written probably in 1913, about the time he was working on ''Sons and Lovers,'' is interesting in so many ways that it's hard to know where to begin. For one thing it was literally a script tossed in a drawer and forgotten, remarkable given the pedigree of the author, and it was neither published nor performed in Lawrence's lifetime. Astonishingly, it was not seen until the Royal Court in London put it on in 1967. That it remains an obscure work is equally surprising, because Lawrence's tale of a marriage strained by class conflict is so well-constructed, so brutally intimate and so psychologically shrewd that it has the prescience and dimensions of an important modernist work.
docs.abstract: Bruce Weber reviews Mint Theater Company production of D H Lawrence play The Daughter-in-Law, directed by Martin L Platt; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The midwives at New York-Presbyterian Hospital can easily keep in touch with former clients: a walk to the local playground is often enough to bump into a mother and child they served. Midwives like that. They pride themselves on long-term, holistic relationships with women before, during and after pregnancy. But come October, the hospital will curtail midwives' role in the major event in these relationships, the actual delivery.

headline.main: Midwives Fear for Their Role In Hospital Deliveries

docs.abstract: Group of 21 midwives appeal to local officials and to American College of Nurse-Midwives over decision by New York-Presbyterian Hospital to curtail their role in delivering babies; hospital senior vice president Cynthia Sparer cites analysis showing that 85 percent of pregnant patients have risk factor; photo (M)
